class.name: XYZ
class.summary:
The CIE XYZ color space is one of the earliest mathematical representation of all colors visible to the human eye, serving as a standard reference for other color spaces.
It's defined by three imaginary primary colors (X, Y, and Z), where Y represents luminance (brightness), and X and Z represent chromaticity (color).
This space is device-independent, meaning it can be used to describe colors without being tied to a specific display or printing technology.
The XYZ color space serves as a fundamental reference for many other color spaces, but distances in this space do not directly reflect perceived color differences as accurately as LAB or LUV.
The XYZ color space is often used as a reference to convert from one color space to another, making it a crucial tool in color management.

interface.name: XYZInt
interface.summary:
RGB decimal value from or to create Color.
If alpha or transparency is included it will be ignored.

interface.name: XYZColor
interface.summary:
Color object to build RGB decimal value from or to create Color.
If alpha or transparency is included it will be ignored.

method.name: AdaptXyz
method.summary:
Performs chromatic adaptation on an XYZ color from a source illuminant to a destination illuminant using the Bradford (von Kries) method.
- The source XYZ color.
- The source illuminant (e.g., Common.D65).
- The destination illuminant (e.g., Common.D50).
method.returns: A new XyzSpace color adapted to the new illuminant.

property.name: Y
property.summary:
'Y' specifically represents the luminance or perceived brightness of the color.
Using example color Azure (#F0FFFF), "XYZ [90, 97, 109]", 'Y' value of 97 confirms that Azure is a very bright color and consistent with its high lightness values in LCH and LAB.

property.name: Z
property.summary: Higher 'Z' values (which are more sensitive to blue light) and higher 'Y' values (for brightness) relative to 'X' values are characteristic of light blue colors.
